awd_titl_txt: CCE STEM: Standard: Collaborative Research:  The Development of Ethical Cultures in Computer Security Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer security researchers prevent, discover, and fix flaws in devices and cyberinfrastructures, thereby impacting national security, business practices, information privacy, and personal safety.  However, these researchers must also navigate ethical dilemmas about how to use big data and shared networked resources to discover vulnerabilities; how to safely expose these problems; and how to best ensure that critical vulnerabilities are fixed.  This proposed research will analyze the scholarly discourse and private reflections of computer security researchers over time. The goal is to reveal insights about how people, changes in technology, and changes in research practices shaped ethical cultures in security research and how ethics shaped research practice.  Through this analysis of a technical research community, the proposed research will demonstrate how an ethical culture was developed and sustained in order to explore the limits of ethical self-regulation.  It will identify the strengths and weaknesses of ethics self-regulation and draw upon ethical practices within computer security to inform other computing research communities.  Project outcomes will contribute to ethics pedagogy for information and computing researchers and develop case studies for use by students and practitioners that demonstrate best practices for self-regulation.

The proposed research will utilize multiple methods, including citation analysis, content analysis, and interviews, to illuminate and evaluate the ethical culture of computer security research.  The project asks four questions: R1) How has the computer security community formed an ethical research culture? R2) How are ethics expectations communicated among researchers? R3) What sociotechnical factors support and challenge sustaining ethical practices? R4) How effective is ethical self-regulation in computer security research? The research will be conducted in four phases.  Phase I will examine the development of ethics controversies and community responses through an analysis of key ethics moments in the last twenty years of computer security research through citation and discourse analysis.  Phase II will interview diverse computer security researchers identified by the citation and discourse analysis to trace how the community developed and changed its approach to ethics over time.  Phase III will conduct a stakeholder assessment of the strengths and weaknesses of ethical self-regulation in computer security research.  Phase IV will create and evaluate educational case studies based on the empirical findings for students, as well as policy recommendations for conference review committees and researchers struggling to identify best practices for ethical computer security research.

por.por_cntn:
This project has studied contrasting forms of ethics work within computer security research, which has grappled with the ethical implications of its work for decades. We compared and contrasted ethics work within computer security to: 1) identify the strengths and weaknesses of ethics self-regulation in this community and 2) examine the applicability and potential of ethical practices within computer security to other computing research communities. Our case studies included guidelines for responsible research in network and computer security. Subsequent requirements for ethics statements in conferences illustrate the use of governance to surface computing ethics. Finally, we looked at activism and advocacy to shape a more ethical future of computing and influenced many of today's leading Internet watchdog and activist groups. Our outcomes include answers four research questions:

R1) How has the computer security community formed an ethical research culture?

We researched changing definitions of "responsibility" in the computer security research community, we conducted oral histories with former members of the Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility (CPSR) and historical document analysis.  We characterize an important instance of collective responsibility for computing by tracing the evolution of CPSR?s first decade of practices, techniques, and arguments. The results of this work were presented at ICA in 2018, RESAW in 2019 and published in 2020 in Internet Histories.

R2) How are ethics expectations communicated among researchers?

Our research -- across survey, interviews, and analysis of scholarly communication -- finds that when computing security researchers do ethics work, they are not consulting ethics statements or reasoning from first principles, they are undertaking ethics with what is at hand in their work environment (building on STS research). That is, they work and learn about ethics with a "habitus" including university lawyers, advisors, lab members, technical program committees, and colleagues. We examined ethics work by technical actors attempting to interpret and close social controversies through interviews and analysis of the 2012 Menlo Report. We produced a model describing the governance and communication process undertaken in the Menlo Report work. Our paper documenting the work and consequences of the Menlo Report was presented at SHOT SIGCIS 2021 and is currently under review. 

R3) What sociotechnical factors support and challenge sustaining ethical practices?

We found that ethical practice is supported by 1) identifying and attending to different relations of power and 2) getting computer scientists to see themselves as ethical actors. But 1) and 2) remain serious challenges in education. Se we developed 2 interventions: First, an ethics reflection exercise for instructors called "Writing Security: Teaching Security Ethics Through Policy Writing" presented in a poster for the 2021 iConference (nominated for best poster award). Second, we then developed material to run a semester-long ethics intervention in an undergraduate computer security class in Fall of 2020 and to appear at ACM SIGCSE 2022. The intervention was incorporated into the UW computer security core curriculum and into their undergraduate capstone course. Finally, we developed 5 eLearning modules on Blockchain Ethics, to teach ethical software development practices.

R4) How effective is ethical self-regulation in computer security research?

In our project, we explored ethics guidelines, advocacy, and governance. Each has implications for doing ethics at scale has opportunities and limitations. In our research we spoke with dozens of participants; none felt that their work was complete. Many had regrets and worried that they had "dropped the ball" at some point or that their task was overwhelming. Cultural change for ethics and responsibility is slow, non-linear, and requires multiple ? sometimes even competing ? tactics.

Intellectual merit: 

This research has demonstrated how different forms of ethics work in computer security were developed and sustained through adaptation of existing resources, and has explored the limits of ethical self-regulation, which range from challenges of enrolling whole communities in new norms to challenges from funding and sustainability. The project has also identified strengths and weaknesses of ethics self-regulation in this community and used these findings to improve ethics pedagogy for information and computing researchers. 

Broader Impacts:

Moving beyond reactive "techlash," tech workers and computing researchers desiring systemic ethical change can be inspired by ethics work in the history of computer security while appreciating the trade-offs and understanding the uphill nature of organized, sustained, and collective ethics work at scale. We have produced a variety of products so that our findings reach large publics. We have shared our findings in an accessible piece documenting our findings in Communications of the ACM. We have also created, evaluated and published extensive curricular materials for computer security and computer ethics courses. And we have used project findings to influence three major professional society ethical projects: ACM SIGCHI's research ethics committee, IEEE's Blockchain Initiative, and the National Academies' Computer Science and Telecommunications Board committee on "Responsible Computing Research: Ethics and Governance of Computing Research and its Applications."
